Title:
Two new Rinodina lichens from South Korea, with an updated
key to the species of Rinodina in the far east Asia
Abstract:
Rinodina salicis Lee & Hur and Rinodina zeorina Lee
& Hur are described as new lichen-forming fungi from wetlands or a
humid forest in South Korea. Rinodina salicis is distinguishable from
Rinodina excrescens Vain., the most similar species, by blastidiate to
tiny areolate, olive-gray thallus, contiguous apothecia, non-pruinose
discs, paler disc color, Pachysporaria-type II ascospore, wider
ascospores, and the absence of secondary metabolites. Rinodina zeorina
differs from Rinodina hypobadia Sheard by areolate and brownish thallus
without distinct margin, non-pruinose apothecia, colorless and wider
parathecium, narrower paraphyses with non-pigmented and unswollen tips,
longer and narrower ascospores with angular to globose lumina, lighter
pigmentation in hypothecium, and the absence of pannarin. Molecular
analyses employing internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences strongly
support the two new species to be unique in the genus Rinodina. An
updated key is provided to assist in the identification of all 61 taxa
in Rinodina of the far east Asia.
